history.content:
I would def. recommend having E25/E26/E27 or E26/E29 before taking ME 102B. You need to have a solid background in 3D modeling, engineering drawings, and manufacturing/tolerancing to get the most out of the class! You should also be relatively comfortable with physics mechanics.

In terms of differences between the two, 102B will spend a bit more time on mechanical design, and you'll become fully machine shop trained as a part of the course! The project is semester-long, versus a couple weeks at the end, and is pretty much entirely open-ended.

102B also focuses a lot on the details of different motors - you'll learn motor control strategies, a lot about PWM, and the pros/cons of different motor types.

children.subject:
102B does have teaching components! There are I think two hours of lecture a week, where you discuss some of the theory behind design and motor stuff. You'll learn a lot about components of mechanical systems (bearings, gears, etc.) as well as details of stepper, servo, and other motors. This is the the most recent in-person syllabus if that's helpful!

If you're interested in a course with really no prereqs other than programming that covers intro to building robotics and stuff, check out ME 135 (Design of microprocessor based mechanical systems) - I think this might be exactly what you're looking for. I believe it's going to be held in the spring, and the projects are of a similar style to 102B - it's much more of an intro class!

Ah yeah. Probably should have clarified that I've taken E26 and E29. Thank you very much for this info btw. One other thing. Does 102B have any teaching components, like will they teach some common techniques / practices or any actual content beforehand, or are you off the get-go having to form a team and create a project? And would you say 102B or 192 is easier as an introductory course? (since I don't have much robotics or mechatronics experience at all)
106A is on mathematics of robot manipulation and programming, vs the electronics/embedded systems/mechatronics and design side of things!
Any reason you wouldn’t want to take EE C106A? That’s the official intro to robotics course, and if you don’t have much experience with robotics i would think that’s the course for you.

history.content:
Anyone know which class would be better for beginner-like students looking in getting involved with electronics and building robots? I don't really have a ton of experience with robotics or mechatronics, but it definitely looks like a super fun and interesting field that I'd want to try out. I'll have completed all of the pre-reqs for both courses by the time I take them (except for stuff like E25 & E27), so preparation for either class shouldn't be an issue.

A quick google search turned up many different types of interesting projects for ME 102B, whereas EE 192 seems to be all an autonomous car project. However, EE 192 does seem to have several weeks dedicated to teaching content, and I'm not sure if any material is even taught in 102B since it seems like much more of a design-based lab class. So, any clarifications on the difference between classes would be appreciated as well.
history.subject: EE 192 vs ME 102B
